lead_paragraph: The measure, which affects public servants, journalists and teachers, will alter a country where meals, cash and other gifts have long been central to doing business.

headline.print_headline: Antigraft Law Stirs Up Wariness on Gift-Giving in South Korea
headline.main: Antigraft Law Stirs Up Wariness Over South Koreans Bearing Gifts

snippet: The measure, which affects public servants, journalists and teachers, will alter a country where meals, cash and other gifts have long been central to doing business....
abstract: South Korean law aimed at curbing corruption linked to gift-giving is expected to force major changes in traditional etiquette; owners of restaurants, common site of conflicts of interest, are especially concerned by prohibition on public officials accepting free meals worth more than $27.
